title:

Do the following statements agree with the information given in Reading Passage 1? 
In boxes 9-13 on your answer sheet, write 
TRUE             if the statement agrees with the information 
FALSE            if the statement contradicts the information 
NOT GIVEN   if there is no information on this
questionText: 9. Children with good self-control are known to be likely to do well at school later on.
10. The way a child plays may provide information about possible medical problems.
11. Playing with dolls was found to benefit girls' writing more than boys' writing.
12. Children had problems thinking up ideas when they first created the story with Lego.
13. People nowadays regard children's play as less significant than they did in the past.

title:
Questions 19 and 20 
Choose TWO letters, A-E. 
Write the correct letters in boxes 19 and 20 on your answer sheet.
questionText:
Which TWO of the following statements are made in the text about the Amsterdam 
bike-sharing scheme of 1999?
options: A. It was initially opposed by a government department
B. It failed when a partner in the scheme withdrew support.
C. It aimed to be more successful than the Copenhagen scheme
D. It was made possible by a change in people's attitudes.
E. It attracted interest from a range of bike designers.
correctAnswer: B. It failed when a partner in the scheme withdrew support.
D. It was made possible by a change in people's attitudes.

title:
Questions 21 and 22 
Choose TWO letters, A-E. 
Write the correct letters in boxes 21 and 22 on your answer sheet.
questionText: Which TWO of the following statements are made in the text about Amsterdam today?
options: A. The majority of residents would like to prevent all cars from entering the city.
B. There is little likelihood of the city having another bike-sharing scheme.
C. More trips in the city are made by bike than by any other form of transport.
D. A bike-sharing scheme would benefit residents who use public transport.
E. The city has a reputation as a place that welcomes cyclists.
correctAnswer: D. A bike-sharing scheme would benefit residents who use public transport.
E. The city has a reputation as a place that welcomes cyclists.

Alexander Henderson

Early life

Travelling as a professional photographer

Ventilation in 19th-century hospital wards

- These were blamed for the spread of disease for hundreds of years, including epidemics of (26) .................. in London and Paris in the middle of the 19th century.

questionText: Which TWO of the following make insects interesting for drug research?
options: A. the huge number of individual insects in the world
B. the variety of substances insects have developed to protect themselves
C. the potential to extract and make use of insects' genetic codes
D. the similarities between different species of insect
E. the manageable size of most insects
correctAnswer: A. the huge number of individual insects in the world
B. the variety of substances insects have developed to protect themselves

questionText:
--------- Guided play ---------
- In the simplest form of guided play, an adult contributes to the environment in which the child is playing.
- Alternatively, an adult can play with a child and develop the play, for instance by (37) ............................ the child to investigate different aspects of their game.
- Adults can help children to learn through play, and may make the activity rather structured, but it should still be based on the child's (38) ............................ to play.

- With adults, play can be (40) ............................ at particular goals.
- However, all forms of play should be an opportunity for children to have fun.

title:

questionText: Which TWO of the following are stated about zoo staff in the text?
options: A. Some take part in television documentaries about animals.
B. Some travel to overseas locations to join teams in zoos.
C. Some get experience with species in the wild before taking up zoo jobs.
D. Some teach people who are involved with conservation projects.
E. Some specialise in caring for species which are under threat.
correctAnswer: A. Some take part in television documentaries about animals.
B. Some travel to overseas locations to join teams in zoos.

title:

questionText: Which TWO of these beliefs about zoos does the writer mention in the text?
options: A They can help children overcome their fears of wild animals.
B They can increase public awareness of environmental issues.
C They can provide employment for a range of professional people.
D They can generate income to support wildlife conservation projects.
E They can raise animals which can later be released into the wild.
correctAnswer: A They can help children overcome their fears of wild animals.
B They can increase public awareness of environmental issues.

 - plastic (not metal or wood)

- most of them focused on individual animals, not entire (36)...................

-- numbers of animals which could be affected 
-- the impact of a reduction in numbers on the (38)............................. of that 
species 
-- the impact on the ecosystem 
Rochman says more information is needed on the possible impact of future (39).............................. (e.g. involving oil).

correctAnswer: A. Assessing the threat of marine debris

questionText:
___________The first urban bike-sharing scheme___________
The first bike-sharing scheme was the idea of the Dutch group Provo. The people who belonged to this group were (23)............................... 
They were concerned about damage to the environment and about (24).............................., and believed that the bike-sharing scheme would 
draw attention to these issues. As well as painting some bikes white, they handed out (25).............................. that condemned the use of cars.
However, the scheme was not a great success: almost as quickly as Provo left the bikes around the city, the (26)..............................took them away. 
According to Schimmelpennink, the scheme was intended to be symbolic. The idea was to get people thinking about the issues.

12. Everyone can develop the same abilities.
13. People of low intelligence are likely to lead uncontrolled lives.

title:
Questions 21 and 22

questionText: Which TWO of the following features make insects valuable for drug research?
options: A. the enormous population size of insects worldwide
B. the wide variety of protective substances insects have developed
C. the possibility of using insects’ genetic material to produce compounds
D. the similarities found among different insect species
D. the similarities found among different insect species
correctAnswer: B. the wide variety of protective substances insects have developed
C. the possibility of using insects’ genetic material to produce compounds

Research at Aberystwyth University
Ross Piper and fellow zoologists at Aberystwyth University are using their expertise in (23).................. when undertaking bioprospecting with insects. They are especially interested in the compounds that insects produce to overpower and preserve their (24)................... They are also interested in compounds which insects use to protect themselves from pathogenic bacteria and fungi found in their (25)..................Piper hopes that these substances will be useful in the development of drugs such as (26).................. antibiotics.

title:

questionText:
Guided play

In the simplest form of guided play, an adult contributes to the environment in which the child is playing. 
Alternatively, an adult can play with a child and develop the play, for instance by (37)...................the child to 
investigate different aspects of their game. Adults can help children to learn through play, and may make the
 activity rather structured, but it should still be based on the child’s (38)................... to play.

Play without the intervention of adults gives children real (39)...................; with adults, play can be (40)...................
 at particular goals. However, all forms of play should be an opportunity for children to have fun.

questionText: Which TWO of the following are stated about zoo staff in the text?
options: A. Some take part in television documentaries about animals.
B. Some travel to overseas locations to join teams in zoos.
C. Some get experience with species in the wild before taking up zoo jobs.

questionText: Which TWO of these beliefs about zoos does the writer mention in the text?
options: A. They can help children overcome their fears of wild animals.
B. They can increase public awareness of environmental issues.
C. They can provide employment for a range of professional people.
D. They can generate income to support wildlife conservation projects.

correctAnswer: B. They can increase public awareness of environmental issues.
